It actually seems like the imperfection in the market is not because of the market, it's because of external forces, like governments and state borders. Wouldn't it be more analogous to say that there is a boson that is preventing the perfect exchange of energy that we predict with the standard model? So it's not really the "free hand" of the market/the particle's momentum that's the problem, it's the externally imposed exchange mechanism?

Side note: In your example, arbitrage IS the invisible hand. The point of the "invisible hand" is that when static shocks happen in an economy, self interest (such as arbitrage) move it back into equilibrium.

Just like any dynamic system, the economy and its steady states are always changing. The cool thing is that when static shocks occur, there exist "invisible" forces that push the market back toward equilibrium (as opposed to needing a central planner to make it so).

The "invisible hand" is not the erroneous assertion that the economy will always remain in equilibrium or even that no externalities will ever exist. Rather, it is the observation that given well-defined property rights, self interest seems to guide the economy toward efficiency and productivity. When viewing the economy as a changing system (rather than a snapshot in time), this indeed appears to be the case.

The photons that hit the retina of your eyes. The chemical reactions at the synapses of your neurons, and their innate ability to conjure a conscious experience... All of this; it's not energy. It's irreversible value exchanges that increase the entropy, until the universe comes at peace; final entropy, equilibrium, heat death. Death.
Fundamentally, the universe only exists as a measurable entity because it's decaying.
Fundamentally, Life only exists through Death.
We spend our whole lives running away from death, pursuing life... while they are in fact one and the same.

2:15 "...and this transfer of value happens solely because we measure value differently in different places"

I'd have to disagree with that statement. Arbitrage isn't possible because we MEASURE VALUE DIFFERENTLY in different places. It's possible because we VALUE THINGS DIFFERENTLY in different places. Even if all countries were to hypothetically use the same currency, arbitrage could still happen simply because sheep are more abundant and desired in some places than others. In fact, the differences in their value would be more obvious and easy to measure in such a scenario.

Although the analogy isn't really a "direct application", it still gets the point across. So kudos nonetheless! :)

An example of measuring things differently in different spots.

Gravity is caused by matter and energy slowing down time relative to an object in deep space. That is time is running slower in the center of a gravity well than it is in space. Because the speed of light is constant this also means space is measured differently (ct = d  so if c is constant and t changes d must change also). 

No astronaut is going to feel time running faster because: 

1) the effect is small for Earth's gravity well

2) EVERYTHING in the astronaut's frame of reference is moving slightly faster than it is on the surface of the Earth. Because everything is moving faster by exactly the same amount no one notices in the astronaut's frame. This is the same reason why a movie will still play out the same events whether it is fast-forwarded, running normal, or on slow. The entities within the movie won't know the difference but the relative difference between two movies running at different speeds can have an effect. This effect is the force of gravity.

In Quantum Field Theory fields develop by thinking of empty space as an infinite number of infinitely thin walls stacked up one after another with an infinite number of holes that are infinitely close. Free space is an infinite number of infinite slit experiments in that theory. This would form an extremely fine series of grids (the grids may have real thickness and the holes may not be infinitely small or infinitely close together but QFT assumes this; in any case they're very tiny). Each one of these grids would be one of the countries. Waves travel through these fine grids and interfere with themselves forming "wave packets" that can propagate like particles. A LASER, an LRAD, or a phased array radar also adds up a whole bunch of waves to make a particle like beam.  

Each one of the grids can measure something like space and time a little differently leading to a net transfer of momentum (force is momentum change over time). This net transfer is carried off by a force carrier.

A repulsive force can be thought of as a force carrier shooting from one particle to another. With this circumstance even macroscopic objects would repel. For example if I shoot a gun my body will want to recoil backwards and the object I hit with the bullet will recoil away from me. Myself and the object I hit will repel.

Attraction is a little harder to visualize and it can only form in a wavelike field (as I described above). A simple example of attraction: given the right wave structure two boats on an ocean can actually attract because the wave structure between the two boats is actually less intense than the rest of the ocean. If the boats are creating their own waves it can be more intense or less intense between them than neutral ocean depending on how those waves are setup. The attractive Casimir Effect would be a similar phenomena . The waves interacting between two charged particles can actually net cancel each other causing a negative transfer of momentum or they can net add creating a positive transfer of momentum. It depends on the modes of the waves (how they are vibrating/setup). There would still be a transfer of a photon in either case. Just in one case if would be a photon carrying a positive momentum and in the other a photon carrying a negative momentum.

The analogies I used here aren't exactly analogous to full quantum fields but they're as close as I could think of. Remember there's a wavelike structure within the transfer. The force carriers between two charges are also what's called virtual particles. That is they don't have to last long enough to fully exist on their momentum/mass shell.

A quick update: the standard model has already incorporated a solution formula on which weak nuclear force, strong nuclear force and electromagnetic force are THE SAME force. Yes. They are the same force. But when applied a different level of energy, the result of this force is so different that they end up looking like three different forces.

So... it is proven by math that the weak nuclear force, the strong nuclear force and the electromagnetic force are just three different behaviors of the same weak-strong-electromagnetic-force at extremely different energy levels; but this leaves us with a question: is gravity also part of this force? Or is gravity a force on its own?

At least, we went from 4 forces to 2 forces. The theory of everything is getting stronger by the day, and we getting closer to a more truthful description of how matter interacts.

In a market transaction the two exchanged items are NEVER equally valuable two either property owner. If you'd value another good equally as high as what you already have you wouldn't trade. What are you talking about. You clearly don't understand the concept of buying power. The buying power of a certain currency is not affected by the value of goods. Just because Canadians may value a certain good less than us does nothing to change the buying power or value of the currency. If a currency has less buying power it is because the currency itself has less value not the good. If USD = CAD then they can be exchanged 1:1 and therefore have the same buying power. They are equal.
In real life, the dollars are almost identical, but as he said, "Canadians may value their sheep less than us". This gives the USD a different buying power than the CAD in this scenario.

Money is itself a commodity subject to supply and demand, once you understand this it becomes clear that the invisible hand of the price mechanism is working to bring markets to equilibrium via arbitrage. Why do so many people think that markets are supposed to reach equilibrium faster than the speed of light? No adjustment period just immediate equilibrium. "So much for the invisible hand..." stick to physics your economics is rusty.

The invisible hand is the price mechanism, in this case arbitragers see that there is a greater demand for money in one market relative to the goods/assets it can buy and engage in arbitrage to equalize the values. Their buying and selling is what brings the market to equilibrium, therefore the invisible hand is working. If there were only one market then there would be no relative disequilibrium between two markets to justify arbitrage, and the single market would be in equilibrium already.

The exchange rate chain analogy lacks friction (eg in the form of commissions, etc). If the person wanted USD in the end, there's also risk in that the entire chain might not go through (ie the chain isn't an atomic transaction). Note also that trending towards free markets increases efficiency and decreases friction, but this doesn't mean that the person will wind up with more money in the end since as efficiencies increase, arbitrage scenarios close.

One can't simply unwind a transaction. If I buy a sheep from someone for $2, I can't simply sell the sheep back to them for $2. That person entered into the transaction because they valued the sheep more than the $2 and I valued the $2 more than the sheep. Note that because we both gained value in the transaction, wealth creation is not a zero-sum game. If this isn't very obvious to someone, playing Settlers of Catan makes it more obvious.

No, gravity isn't a force at all. It's an "effect" of a curved and bended spacetime. That's what makes what we feel as gravity. Gravity is just a force what we THINK exists. In fact, it doesn't. The moon orbits the Earth just because it "falls" in a straight line in spacetime. Some kinds of energies, like matter, CURVES the spacetime, and our experience is some kind of force that we just think exists. If that was too hard for you to understand, Google "the theory of Relativity".
